awd_titl_txt: Using Microbial Ecology Theory to Understand Microbial Community Dynamics and Improve Function of Anaerobic Bioreactors
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to understand the interplay between members of the microbial community in anaerobic digesters that convert food waste to useful methane gas to maximize performance and increase the ability of the reactors to handle various food waste types. The key to success is determining how the microbial communities in the reactors that perform the waste-to-gas conversion are assembled under different environmental conditions. The project will involve a deeply integrated program of reactor experiments, molecular analysis, and mathematical modeling. Graduate and undergraduate students, including students from a historically black university, will be trained during the course of this project. The results have the potential to transform our understanding of the science of waste conversion, and benefit municipalities and waste treatment industries as they seek realistic ways of converting waste to energy, thus increasing our energy efficiency while simultaneously reducing waste generation.
 
Directly linking microbial communities to bioreactor function and environmental conditions is a great challenge for biological process engineers. This link can be accomplished by using the ecological theory of microbial community assembly under dynamic conditions to guide the design of hypothesis-driven experiments. The overall objective of this project is to elucidate the relationships between anaerobic co-digester operating conditions, microbial communities, and reactor functions, and to use these insights to achieve faster transitions, higher methane yields, and develop reactors that are more resilient and resistant to perturbations. The specific objectives are: 1) To determine to what extent deterministic and stochastic processes contribute to shaping the assembly in anaerobic co-digesters under changing conditions; 2) To determine the key microbial populations, interactions, and co-occurrences under different and dynamic conditions; 3) To use the insights from microbial community assembly to increase resilience and resistance in response to varying substrate types and loadings, and maintain high methane yields; and, 4) To broaden participation of underrepresented sectors in microbiology and engineering research, and to disseminate the practical implications of the findings to the wastewater community. This study will integrate a methodological and theoretical community assembly frameworks with next generation DNA and RNA sequencing approaches, bioreactor studies, and mathematical modeling to investigate and improve an engineered biological process. This integrated approach represents a novel way of investigating biological processes in engineered systems and opens up a new research field that will address basic questions about anaerobic co-digestion and lead to a better understanding of other biological processes involved in waste treatment, energy production, and resource recovery. This project will contribute to the education of graduate and undergraduate students, including one from St. Augustine's University, for two summers in the areas of engineering, microbiology, and molecular biology. This project will benefit municipal and industrial wastewater treatment plants as they seek sustainable and realistic ways of converting waste to energy. Results from this project will be incorporated in microbiology workshops for wastewater treatment professionals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Anaerobic reactors that co-digest food waste and biosolids need to produce higher methane yields (to maximize waste conversion and energy production) and be more resilient and resistant to perturbations. This depends on understanding the relationships between anaerobic co-digester operating conditions and microbial communities. Using lab-scale experiments, we showed how both changing food waste types (carbohydrates such as vegetables, proteins such as meat, and lipids such as grease interceptor waste) as well as changes in loading affect the microbial communities and methane production. The results show that shifting from one food waste type to another affects the methane generation (e.g., protein to lipids yielded higher methane levels). Another experiment that used different initial microbiomes showed that specialized microbial populations developed by acclimation to specific feed types were more resilient to increased loading. Taken together, the results suggest that influencing the microbial populations through feed type manipulation may result in more resilient anaerobic reactors. The results of the study are being used by the City of Raleigh in their Bioenergy project. We expect other utilities to be able to use these findings to improve their anaerobic digester projects.

We combined computational fluid dynamics (CFD), biokinetics, and physico-microbial processes such as floc diffusion into a single tool based on an open source model platform. The approach was validated in a bench-scale reactor and showed how the integrated model can account for particle sizes of flocs. An analysis of how microbial communities assemble in engineered bioreactors was completed, and the critical review described the different approaches that can be used by researchers. The microbial community assembly during start-up of a full scale wastewater treatment plant was studied and used to determine the contributions of deterministic and stochastic factors. These studies advanced the knowledge of how and to what extent microbial communities can be influenced by operators.

Graduate and undergraduate students were trained in this project. Hundreds of wastewater treatment operators were reached by the PI through training via the Eastern Biological WW School in NC. Hundreds of high school and college students in the US and Philippines were reached via virtual and face-to-face presentations. A collaboration with Malawi universities through a PEER-funded project elaborated on the need for specialized training in sanitation in Malawi. Animated videos (TED-Ed.com) on sanitation and toilets were viewed over 3.6M times globally, thus increasing the general public?s understanding and appreciation for wastewater treatment and access to sanitation services.

 


Last Modified: 12/02/2022
Modified by: Francis L De Los Reyes Iii
